hints_html:
Apply the fundmental theorem of calculus to the integral

\[\begin{aligned} \quad \int_{0}^{x^{2}}f(t)\,dt.\end{aligned}\]
hints_raw:
Apply the fundmental theorem of calculus to the integral 
:<math>
\quad \int_{0}^{x^{2}}f(t)\,dt.
</math>
question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
By the fundamental theorem of calculus, we know that there exists a function g(x) such that

\[\begin{aligned} F(x) = \int_{0}^{x^{2}}f(t)\,dt = g(x^{2}) - g(0)\end{aligned}\]

where g(x) is the anti-derivative of the function f(x) (i.e: g’(x) = f(x)). Taking the derivative of F(x) gives

\[\begin{aligned} F'(x) = \frac{d}{dx}\left(g(x^{2}) - g(0) \right) = g'(x^2)\cdot 2x\end{aligned}\]

by the chain rule. Using the anti-derivative property of g,

\[\begin{aligned} F'(x) = f(x^2)\cdot 2x.\end{aligned}\]

Plugging in x = 2 and using the fact that f(4) = 1 gives us our answer

\[\begin{aligned} F'(2) = f(4)\cdot 4 = 4\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
By the fundamental theorem of calculus, we know that there exists a function g(x) such that

:<math>
F(x) = \int_{0}^{x^{2}}f(t)\,dt = g(x^{2}) - g(0)
</math>

where g(x) is the anti-derivative of the function f(x) (i.e: g'(x) = f(x)). Taking the derivative of F(x) gives

:<math>
F'(x) = \frac{d}{dx}\left(g(x^{2}) - g(0) \right) = g'(x^2)\cdot 2x
</math>

by the chain rule. Using the anti-derivative property of g,

:<math>
F'(x) = f(x^2)\cdot 2x.
</math>

Plugging in x = 2 and using the fact that f(4) = 1 gives us our answer

:<math>
F'(2) = f(4)\cdot 4 = 4
</math>
statement_html:
If

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle F(x) = \int_{0}^{x^{2}}f(t)\, dt,\end{aligned}\]

where \(\displaystyle f\) is a function satisfying \(\displaystyle f(4) = 1\), compute \(\displaystyle F'(2).\)
statement_raw:
If

:<math> \displaystyle F(x) = \int_{0}^{x^{2}}f(t)\, dt, </math>

where <math> \displaystyle f</math> is a function satisfying <math> \displaystyle f(4) = 1</math>, compute <math> \displaystyle F'(2). </math>
